texts.text: My field of view is filled by a stark white ceiling and long, flowing white hair.
Rose-colored eyes look down on me.
For a moment, I could swear she nodded.
Yonagi, who was bending over me, mimics my movement.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: How long did we sleep this time?
I mutter at no one in particular, and am reminded there are no clocks in this place.
I can't tell if I had a light sleep or a deep slumber.
Izumo and Wooleep enter the room.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: You don't need to ask to know, do you?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: You should eat. Your blood sugar levels are low.
It seems like an expression attempts to break through Yonagi's emotionless visage, but it quickly returns to her usual neutral expression.
After staring at me for a moment too long, she gives me a small nod.
When we get to the table, Izumo presents us with the same boiled corn dish from before.
It dawns on me that we'll probably be eating the same thing for as long as we're here.
But it does taste okay, so it'll probably take some time for me to get bored of it.
The only sound in the room is that of spoons clinking against bowls.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Mind if I ask a few more things?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: You know about these dreams I'm having, don't you?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I've never had such vivid dreams before.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It feels like I'm really there. I'm really curious about it.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Ask away. I'll answer as much as I can.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: In short, it is an academic appointment wherein the person only imparts lectures.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: A person in this position is not responsible for tutoring their students like a tenured professor, nor do they have any obligation to get involved with anything outside their assigned teaching syllabus.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Most of the people employed in this capacity are not full-time employees, so they can have side jobs as well.
Arishima may still be harboring hopes of becoming a novelist someday.
Maybe that's why he chose such an arrangement for his employment.
I get the feeling that in his case, it's also a good choice in that it allows him to keep a distance from his students.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So it's a term from the education system from long ago.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I heard of a place called a 'pub' in the dream. What was that about?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: The people of old had a tradition of gathering and eating together outside of their homes.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: At the time, a system of 'currency' was in circulation, and people indirectly exchanged this currency for goods and services.
I feel my eyes widen in incredulous surprise.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Why go through so much trouble?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: The population at that time was much larger than it is now. Rather than bartering, indirect exchange through paper currency was more convenient.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: A pub was a place where you could exchange currency mainly for alcoholic beverages and light meals.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And alcohol was available to any adult?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: If they were older than twenty years old, give or take depending on the region of the world.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: The drinking age was only lowered after we returned to the current barter economy.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Is it true that women weren't allowed to act on stage?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Yes. Back then, it was forbidden for woman to perform. It seems that, back then, female roles were performed by young males before their voices broke.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: In the same vein, women that dressed as men were considered abhorrent, and the act was branded as taboo.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Although progress was slower in some countries, it was not until the nineteenth century that women generally started assuming a more leading role in society.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Too much time, if you ask me...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: A man named Christopher Marlowe appeared in my dream.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: A playwright who was active in England during the sixteenth century.
She's staring absently at nothing like usual.
I then turn back to Izumo.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: William Shakespeare went on to become widely regarded as the greatest writer who ever lived, but at the time of his debut, Christopher Marlowe was a popular household name.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: His most famous works are 'The Jew of Malta' and 'Tamburlaine the Great.' He was a worthy contemporary and rival for Shakespeare.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: If Shakespeare never started writing, perhaps he would have been the most well known writer of the Elizabethan era.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Even taking into account the misfortune of Marlowe's untimely death in the middle of his career, Shakespeare's fame as a writer simply came to eclipse his.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: It is said that the play that brought him fame was Tamburlaine the Great.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: As for the momentum he gained after debuting that play... perhaps he simply lacked the modesty to make use of it.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: In the twentieth century, critics began to argue that his subsequent works were mostly written by other hands.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Even if the first two acts were written by Marlowe, critics speculate that the subsequent three acts may have been written by other people.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That's more than half the play.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: If it had Marlowe's name on it, it would sell.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: At the time, Marlowe may have been dazzled by the allure of reaping easy prestige, rather than than going through the hard work of meticulously honing his craft.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: There are also theories that he was in fact acting as spy in the service of Queen Elizabeth's service.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: As a tipper reporting on the current religious target at the time. The Catholic faith.
It's a secret place of congregation for Catholics.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So he's a pretty clear cut enemy, then.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: At any rate, verifiably accurate data from Shakespeare's time is scarce, and there are many different interpretations and theories. I think you should be aware of that.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah, thanks. That gave me a lot to think about.

selects: What was with all the birds?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: In the dream, I was in a place called Chiba prefecture?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: There were a bunch of white birds there. I think someone called them...

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Pigeons. But they aren't pigeons. They are biological communication devices called artificial pigeons.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Their development was announced by Hazuki Izana in 2031. By the year 2035, five hundred million artificial pigeons were released out to the world as the first test of the system.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: After that, the number of pigeons increased, and a global, cheap, and stable communication network was provided to the whole world.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: On July 10th, 2046, all the artificial pigeons went out of control. Suddenly, they began to emit jamming radio waves all throughout the pigeon network, rendering all electronic communication devices useless.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: This phenomenon is commonly known as the wave eating.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That dream is about the year 2061, so it happens after the wave eating started, right?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: The wave eating was a man-made disaster intentionally brought about by Hazuki Izana. The aftermath of it affected the whole world.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Humanity relied on the pigeon network at the time.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: After the wave eating, the United Nations started a campaign called 'Remember Nature.' Efforts were made to return highly automated jobs and fully automated industries back to human hands and labor.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Public opinion leaned towards anti-technology, and the few means of wired communication were used only by the governments of the world to stay in contact.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So there are no communication devices in that world, huh?
While I've been talking with Izumo, I've managed to clean my plate.
Yonagi has also finished her meal.
Yonagi simply stares at her empty plate.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Mind if I go get some fresh air?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I wanna go take a look at the rooftop you took me to the other day. I can't tell what time it is in here.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: No problem. You do not need permission.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: You may be able to see the sun at this time of the day.
The air outdoors feels a little chilly.
I walk ahead, looking up at the sky.
A wave of relief hits me.
This is the sky I know.
The round sky, surrounded by high walls.
The outside world is just as I... remember.
I look down and see the whole span of the cityscape spreading in front of my eyes.
The familiar sight of the outer walls lined with houses on their surface.
And above that, the sky is blue and the sun dazzling.
This is the world I know.
Without my memories, I can't really judge how much of my perception is correct.
But this is the Japan I know. I know in my heart that this is Shinjuku.
I wonder if anyone has found a way to really stand under that sky.
It doesn't look like much has changed from the mental image I seem to have, so the answer is probably no.
Taking a deep breath, I notice tiny dust particles mixed into the air.
The air indoors is a lot cleaner than outside.
When I get take the elevator and go back to the eating area, I find no one there.
The dishes Yonagi and I used have been put away as well.
Izumo and Wooleep are also nowhere to be seen.
But I don't find anyone in the room either.
I notice a set of clothes neatly folded on my bed.
They're exactly the same as the ones I'm wearing right now.
I lift up my arm and take a whiff.
But perhaps it wouldn't be a bad idea to take a shower before the next dream.
I recall the time Izumo guided me around.
I hear the sound of running water on the other side of the door.
So Yonagi's taking a shower. That makes sense.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Yes. This entire facility is under constant surveillance.
I can hear someone moving around in the shower room.
But just then, the door opens.
Hot steam rolls out into the corridor.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Yonagi is done with her bath. Feel free to enter.
I cautiously step through the steamy entrance.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Go ahead, the bath is open. It's unisex.
Izumo's deadpan tone echoes through the hot room.
Yonagi is looking at me as though I'm just a part of the furniture.
My eyes are helplessly drawn towards the obvious.
Her wet white hair clings to the modest curves of her chest.
Her hair and skin share almost the same shade of white.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I don't think I will, no.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'll come back later. You need time to dry her hair, right?
I can't read any emotions on her face, but the lack of expression itself feels recriminating.
Izumo and Yonagi are staring at me in silence.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'll take a bath next time I wake up. I'm going back to sleep.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: It appears to me that you are in a state of excitement. I believe it will not help you sleep.
If I had my memories, would have I behaved differently?
No, I get the feeling my reaction would be about the same.
I should just go back to bed, before she gets back.
If Yonagi's in the same room, I'm sure I won't be able to sleep well.
Heaving a deep sigh, I head back to the room on my own.
When I stand up, Yonagi does the same.
Yonagi trails after me without saying a word.
Her bare feet slap against the floor.
I turn back and call out to her, which elicits no response from her.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I mean, can I call you Yonagi?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Do you remember how long we have been here?
I face ahead again and go to the elevator leading up to the rooftop.
The elevator door opens in front of us.
A cool air blows onto our faces as it does.
When I move to step outside...
Yonagi stops me, pulling on my sleeve.
Right, the air outside is pretty dusty.
Yonagi stays a few steps behind me as we walk down the corridor to our room.
Once we arrive, she heads straight for her bed.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Do you feel better in here?
Maybe she just doesn't feel like talking.
Instead of answering my question, she lays down on the bed.
She keeps her rose eyes trained on me.
Hearing the door open behind me, I turn back to see Izumo and Wooleep come into the room.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Kaito, do you want to take a shower?
I lift up my arm and take a whiff.
But perhaps it wouldn't be a bad idea to take a shower before the next dream.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah, I guess that'd be nice.
Izumo presents me with a neatly folded set of clothes.
They're exactly the same I'm wearing now.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Is she gonna be okay on her own?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: The shower booth is for one person. You can't bathe together.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That's not what I'm talking about.
Izumo and Yonagi just stare at me silently.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Whatever, I'll just go take a shower.
I get up and head to the door.
Wooleep chirps at me when I pass him. For some reason, I construe it as him calling out to me, so I thank him out of some kind of reflex.
When I come back from the shower, Yonagi's already asleep.
I go to my bed, sit down, and stare at her for a moment.
She's turned over with her back to me.
I lay down on the bed, facing the stark white ceiling.
A weird place, full of weird girls.
My eyelids feel heavy, and opening them back up is feeling like a worse proposition by the minute.
This warmth makes me feel really sleepy.
Izumo said that these dreams are sequenced like stories.
Will I see the continuation of that last dream now?
As my hazy mind vaguely wonders about these dream world memories, I fall into a deep sleep.
When I stand up, Yonagi does the same.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I don't want to go there.
I look between Yonagi and Izumo.
Both of them are staring straight at me.
I turn to Izumo and think for a second.
She nods and leaves her seat.
I follow her out of the dining room.
Once we arrive at the recreation room, Yonagi walks up to the bookshelf, takes out a picture book, and goes to sit down on the floor.
The title on the cover is "Yamanashi."
That is, if my memory-less perception is right.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's amazing how this has stood the test of time.
I sit next to her and look at the pages.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Here are two blue magic lantern slides, projecting the bottom of a small mountain stream.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Two tiny young crabs are playing at the bottom of the blue brook.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: They're animals that live in the water. I haven't actually seen any, though.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah, these ones. See? These two little animals.
I say, pointing at the bright little creatures depicted in the book.
I've never seen a crab in my life.
And as far as I can tell from the picture...
It's not like I have anything else to go on, though.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The ceiling and the sides are like dark blue, impenetrable steel walls. Dark bubbles flow along the smooth, running ceiling.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And this is the end of the magic lantern slide.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I feel sorry for the fish.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah, up next is... The Little Mermaid.
And it's a tragic story too.
After reading four books to her, she begins to rub at her eyes.
Once we arrive at the recreation room, Yonagi goes and takes two dolls from the toybox.
She presents me with a doll that looks like a prince.
She says, holding a doll in a pink dress in her hand.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Prince, are you coming to see me?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And the prince rides this. Here.
Yonagi presents me a brown, four-legged doll.
Yonagi groans, and the doll falls to the floor.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: She'll revive when the prince comes back.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You're riding a horse. It should be faster.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And now that he's here, the prince cries.
I let the doll fall to the floor.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: The princess came back to life.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: She was so sad about the prince dying that she died of sadness.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And they lived happily ever after.
After repeating the same story with the doll three times, she begins rubbing at her eyes.
Once we arrive at the recreation room, Yonagi trots over the the toybox and takes out some paints and a black camera before coming back.
She hands the camera to me.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I am the model, you are my camera man.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Use this to take pictures of me.
Then, she pats at her cheeks.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Oh, I see what you mean.
She says, lightly dusting a paintbrush over her cheeks.
Then she brings the brush to her mouth.
Yonagi drops the brush and picks up another one.
She starts using the paint on her nails.
The paint from last time has already come off.
It probably washes off with water.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And last, I'll do my hair.
She pantomimes cutting her own hair with scissors.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Huh? Err, wh-why do you ask?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You gotta tell me how cute I am.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I'll put on the next dress.
After we've been playing at modeling for a while, Yonagi starts rubbing at her eyes.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Ah, good thing you're here. Yonagi's—

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Yes, It's okay. She can sleep here.
Izumo quickly grabs a blanket from a nearby rack and covers Yonagi with it.
I follow her gaze and look at Yonagi's sleeping face as well.
The corners of her mouth are curled into a placid smile.
Izumo keeps staring at her face as she gently strokes her head.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: You can go to sleep whenever you want.
Now that she mentions it, I'm quite drowsy.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'm a bit sleepy, yeah. I'll go back to my bed.
I turn my back on Yonagi, Izumo, and Wooleep.
As I'm about to go out the door, I look back at the recreation room.
I get the feeling that my comment perplexes her, somehow.
Turning back to the corridor, I leave the room.
I hear her faint response from behind the now closed door.
I walk back to my room feeling strangely calm.
I have no idea what this experiment is for.
But maybe it isn't such a bad idea to cooperate.
Such are the thoughts that cross my mind as I yawn on my way back to bed.
